node.title: Pandemic workers kill pet dog in China while helpless owner watches on
node.alt: A man opens his mouth while a health worker in full PPE holds a swab in front of his face
node.description: The owner of the pet corgi watched the killing via her home security camera, after being forced to leave the dog in her apartment to undergo quarantine.
node.content:
["Warning: this story contains details of animal cruelty that some readers might find distressing", "A pet corgi was brutally killed in China last week as part of an \"epidemic prevention\" effort, sparking a fierce debate on Chinese social media about animal cruelty.", "The dog's owner was in hotel quarantine and watched the attack unfold, using the microphone feature on her home's security camera to plead with the pandemic workers to stop attacking the dog.", "\"I kept begging them through the CCTV not to continue beating [her], but they still didn't listen,\" the woman wrote on Chinese social media platform Weibo.", "\"After the beating, there was blood on the floor and [the dog] ran into [another] room to avoid the beating, so [the whole incident] was not recorded on the CCTV, but tiny screams could be heard.", "\"A few minutes later, with a yellow plastic bag in hand, [the pandemic workers] said they had finished [with the dog] and would take it away.\"", "The woman, identified as Ms Fu in Chinese media, then asked netizens for help to find out what happened to her beloved dog, \"Fried Noodles\".", "", "
A screenshot\u00a0of one of the pet\u00a0owner's original posts on Chinese social media,\u00a0where she voiced her distress.\u00a0(Supplied)
", "Her comments and the vision on CCTV sparked a huge reaction on social media in China, with the hashtag \"a quarantined pet dog in Shangrao was suspected of being killed\" gaining more than 200 million reads on Weibo.", "The pet owner has since deleted her posts but other netizens captured screenshots of her reaction. The ABC has contacted Ms Fu for comment.", "Chinese netizens were outraged and distressed by the situation, calling for animal protection laws in China.", "One Weibo user said\u00a0people \"are concerned that this could happen to them\".", "Another netizen said:\u00a0\"Don't break the hearts of those who are cooperating with the epidemic prevention measures.\"", "", "
Footage shows the corgi hit with an iron bar.(Supplied)
", "
Local authority apologises for dog killing
", "The local government authority for the area where the pet owner lives, in south-east China, issued a statement confirming the dog was killed.", "The government said the pet owner's\u00a0apartment building was an \"epidemic prevention and control zone\" and that \"full disinfection of the home environment\" was required.", "It said the pandemic workers \"disposed of the pet dog harmlessly without adequate communication with the netizen\".", "\"The West City Street Office has criticised and educated the relevant personnel, transferred them from their corresponding positions, and ordered a sincere apology to the person concerned,\" the government statement said.", "In one of the pet owner's now-deleted posts, she said she was asked to go into hotel quarantine because there was a COVID-19 case in her community but had to leave her dog in the apartment.", "She later tested negative to COVID-19, as did the rest of her family.", "In China, there are no uniform regulations on how to deal with domestic pets during their owners' quarantines.", "Shanghai's Huangpu District allows pet owners and pets to\u00a0quarantine in a hotel together, while Beijing's Daxing District allows one family member to stay at home and care for the pet in isolation.", "Beijing's Changping District tests pets for COVID-19 at home, and transfers the pet to a boarding facility.", "It is\u00a0not the first time pets have been killed in China because of COVID-19.", "In September, in Harbin in north-east China, three cats were euthanised after the owner and cats tested positive for COVID-19, which also fuelled a debate online about animal protection in China.", "", "
The dog's owner used the microphone feature on her home's security camera to plead with the pandemic workers to stop attacking the dog.(Pexels: Muhannad Alatawi, file\u00a0)
", "
Pets cannot transmit COVID-19 to people
", "Chinese experts from the Centre for Disease Control recently said there was insufficient data to confirm whether COVID-19 could be transmitted between pets and humans.", "But previous evidence has found domestic\u00a0pets cannot transmit the virus to humans. But humans can transmit the virus to pets.", "", "
Professor James Gilkerson says the best way pet owners can protect their furry pals is to get vaccinated against COVID-19.(Supplied)
", "James Gilkerson, a professor of veterinary microbiology at the University of Melbourne, said there had\u00a0not been any real documented cases of people getting COVID-19 from their pets.", "\"I think the way that pets get COVID-19 is from their owners. So the biggest risk is not that your pet will give you COVID, but that you will give it to your pet.\"", "Professor James said pet owners should get vaccinated.", "\"I think if you can keep yourself safe, you can keep your pet safe,\" he said.", "
Calls for animal protection laws in China
", "With numerous pet cruelty incidents documented\u00a0on social media in recent years, there have\u00a0been\u00a0growing calls in China for anti-animal cruelty and animal protection laws.", "China passed the Wildlife Protection Act in 1988, but there is no uniform law protecting non-wildlife, such as pets.", "Peter Li, associate professor of East Asian politics, University of Houston-Downtown, said mainland China lags behind the first modern anti-cruelty legislation, the Martin's Act of Britain, by about 200 years, a situation that was not in pace with China's economic progress.", "Dr Li said one of the possible reasons for China's lack of anti-cruelty legislation was that it would require higher animal welfare standards for the country's livestock industry.", "He said since China was the world's biggest meat and egg producer, with the\u00a0biggest livestock output, the adoption of an animal protection law would require improved farming conditions and lead to increased production cost.", "Government offices in charge of animal agriculture may also resist such policy change, he added.", "\"Others would object to animal protection on account of the need to care for humans first. This attitude is in fact quite common among the people,\" he said.", "\"Animal protection laws can help enhance China's attractiveness and soft power and serve as a deterrence against animal cruelty.\""]
